Comment: This is a nice little game in which I sacrificed a knight for the attack. Nothing very interesting happens until move 18, so feel free to skip ahead. I'll be posting my thoughts rather than computer evaluations.
I played a couple of games using this line of Caro-Kann. The h-pawn advance kind of disrupts my kingside, so in these situations I castle queenside.

I need to advance the g-pawn, so the knight on g3 needs to go.

If he recaptures with the knight, than e5 is free for my own knight.

In this position, I considered Bxh6 and Ng6, but neither of them looked very promising at the time.

Now that I control g4, I can safely advance the g-pawn and prepare for g5.
Now that I control g4, I can safely advance the g-pawn and prepare for g5.
Obviously, black counterattacks on the other flank.
I also considered 17.Qb3, but I preferred to keep my queen on the b1-h7 diagonal.
Applying some pressure on the d-column. A reasonable move, but now, f7 is exposed.

I felt this move would spice things up a bit. My plan at this point is 19.Qg6+, 20.g5 and try to focus all my forces towards his (hopefully exposed) king. A knight sac on f7 certainly isn't original; it was the first move that came to my mind and "felt" right. The computer (Crafty) prefers 18.g5, but this is more interesting and I fancy myself playing like Morphy. Minus the genius part.
Sacrifice accepted and acknowledged.
The obvious continuation.
I also considered 20.Bxh6, but I'd rather try to open up the g-column. Besides, I didn't have the guts for a second sacrifice :) (I bet Morphy wouldn't have hesitated for a second)
I also considered 20.Bxh6, but I'd rather try to open up the g-column. Besides, I didn't have the guts for a second sacrifice :) (I bet Morphy wouldn't have hesitated for a second)
Black chooses to retreat and keep an eye on h6 and f6.
I try to keep the pressure on.
I didn't realize at the time, but apparently this is THE mistake, because now the g aisle is wide open. Computer evaluation is +6.5, aka "+-" for 21..gxh6 and only +2.8 (+/-) for 21..Nxh6
I briefly thought about 22.Bxh6, but this looks more promising. I threaten both 23.Qxg8+ and 23.Qg7+ and there is no way black can avoid both.
Maybe there is a way after all. I'm sorry to say I didn't see this, but it's only temporary.
